statement.text: Transperitoneal aortic exposure through a midline laparotomy is the classic approach to the infrarenal aorta. The technique requires retracting the small bowel, mobilizing the duodenum (Kocher maneuver equivalent), and incising the retroperitoneal ligament of Treitz to expose the aorta from the left renal vein to the iliac bifurcation. This approach provides excellent exposure of both iliac arteries and allows concomitant intraperitoneal procedures.
statement.formal: Transperitoneal Exposure: Midline laparotomy → Eviscerate/retract small bowel → Incise retroperitoneum over aorta → Identify left renal vein (proximal landmark) → Expose infrarenal aorta → Control iliacs | Advantages: Familiar anatomy, bilateral iliac access, concurrent procedures | Disadvantages: Bowel manipulation, ileus, adhesion potential

explanation.intuition: The transperitoneal approach is like opening the hood of a car to work on the engine - you're lifting everything out of the way to see the main structure underneath. The intestines are moved aside (or wrapped up and placed on the chest), and you cut through the tissue covering the aorta to expose it. It's more invasive but gives you a great view of everything.
explanation.key_insight: The left renal vein crossing the aorta is your proximal landmark for infrarenal aortic exposure. Find this vein and you know exactly where your proximal clamp can go safely above it. The vein can be ligated if needed (as long as the gonadal and adrenal tributaries are preserved), but try to avoid it as it can cause renal vein hypertension.
explanation.technical_details: Technique: (1) Midline incision from xiphoid to pubis; (2) Enter peritoneum; (3) Eviscerate small bowel to right, wrap in moist towel or place in bowel bag; (4) Retract transverse colon superiorly; (5) Incise retroperitoneum over aorta, starting at level of ligament of Treitz; (6) Extend incision from left renal vein to bifurcation; (7) Identify left renal vein crossing aorta anteriorly; (8) Control aorta below left renal vein; (9) Ligate and divide lumbar veins for circumferential control; (10) Identify and preserve inferior mesenteric artery (divide if needed); (11) Expose iliac arteries by extending retroperitoneal incision; (12) Identify and protect ureters. For suprarenal control: Mobilize left renal vein, divide if needed, expose suprarenal aorta.
common_misconceptions: You always need to ligate the left renal vein for exposure - usually you can work around it
The IMA must be preserved - it can be ligated if collaterals are adequate
Transperitoneal approach has worse outcomes - outcomes are similar to retroperitoneal
Ileus is unavoidable - gentle handling and early feeding minimize duration

definitions_glossary.ligament_of_treitz: Suspensory ligament of duodenum, landmark for retroperitoneal incision
definitions_glossary.left_renal_vein: Vein crossing anterior to aorta, proximal landmark for infrarenal exposure
definitions_glossary.inferior_mesenteric_artery: Branch of aorta supplying left colon, may need ligation
definitions_glossary.lumbar_veins: Paired segmental veins to IVC, must ligate for aortic mobilization
definitions_glossary.iliac_bifurcation: Division of aorta into common iliac arteries

indications: Bilateral iliac artery disease requiring exposure
contraindications: Multiple prior laparotomies with hostile abdomen (relative - consider retroperitoneal)
Obese patient (may be technically easier retroperitoneal)

technique.positioning: Supine with arms out or at sides

incision.modification: Can extend around umbilicus or excise umbilicus if needed

key_structures.left_renal_vein: Crosses anterior to aorta, proximal landmark - protect or divide if needed
key_structures.inferior_mesenteric_artery: Arises from anterolateral aorta - preserve if possible
key_structures.ureters: Cross iliac arteries - identify and protect
key_structures.iliac_veins: Deep to arteries - avoid injury during iliac exposure

steps: Make midline incision from xiphoid to pubis
Eviscerate small bowel to right upper quadrant
Incise retroperitoneum over aorta at ligament of Treitz
Identify left renal vein crossing aorta
Extend retroperitoneal incision over iliac arteries
Control iliac arteries for planned procedure

extensions.suprarenal_exposure: Mobilize left renal vein (divide if necessary), divide left crus
extensions.thoracoabdominal: Extend through left chest for descending thoracic aorta
extensions.bilateral_iliac: Extend retroperitoneal incision to both iliac arteries

complications.prevention: Gentle bowel handling, early feeding when tolerated
complications.management: NG tube if prolonged, dietary advancement as tolerated

complications.prevention: Identify ureters early, protect during iliac exposure

complications.management: Direct repair or ligation (if gonadal/adrenal tributaries intact)

complications.prevention: Careful dissection, veins are deep to arteries

definition.@value: Surgical exposure of the abdominal aorta through a midline laparotomy and transperitoneal approach

sources.citation: Rutherford's Vascular Surgery, 9th Edition. Aortic Exposure Techniques.

learning_objectives: Describe the anatomy encountered during transperitoneal aortic exposure
Perform midline laparotomy and expose the infrarenal aorta
Identify and protect critical structures (renal vein, IMA, ureters)
clinical_pearls: The left renal vein is your landmark - find it and you know where the infrarenal aorta starts
The IMA can be ligated if the marginal artery (Arc of Riolan) and hypogastrics are patent
Identify both ureters before doing iliac work - they cross the iliac arteries
Wrap the small bowel in a moist towel to prevent desiccation during long cases
This is the approach most surgeons use for ruptured AAA - familiar and fast
